descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses I try to be balanced so, despite being anti-racist and pro-green, I feel I must say I don't think being free to create a public nuisance is the same thing as being free to speak.

The non-violent protestors alongside the rioters last week felt their cause was just too. Some of them seem to have been arrested for less, by association, and that leads to accusations of 2-tier policing. I also think radical action can hurt political causes. Liberty needs a 'right to ignore'.

account.note:
Data physicist, information philosopher & network culture theorist.
Writes in Obsidian, computes in Clojure, using emacs with Cider. Less is more. Small pieces, loosely joined, for emergent complexity.
Agile software development with models, functions, graphs & flow. Not tech: @wootube@mastodonapp.uk

descendants.content:
@woo @breadandcircuses

Two things:

1. Radical action may hurt political causes, but non-radical action leads nowhere in most cases. Look at what has changed in this world from not bothering anyone and compare them to the things that changed after significant actions.

2. The fact that people have been arrested for less doesn't invalidate the case against this abuse. Prisons are supposed to house individuals that present a danger to the others (voluntary "the" use here). These people don't, therefore, belong in prison. This applies to everything, not just activism.

descendants.content: @arh @woo @breadandcircuses I think "validate" is meant here, if I'm reading this correctly. Prison is overused, & there are far more people in jail than there should be, serving far longer sentences than they ought to be - & I'm not just talking about climate & other activists.

I like films, classical music, jazz, and reading.

descendants.content:
@arh @breadandcircuses To paraphrase: "the only way to get anything changed is to break the law". Is 'Anarchy in the UK' OK now? It clearly was for the 'disenfranchised' racist rioters who don't vote.
"Might is Right". Is that OK?
"If the police don't come when you are robbed, keep a machete by the door and deal with them yourself. There's not a court in the land that would convict you." Very Wild West. That's what kids say to justify carrying a bladed weapon. "It's only for defence".
